text: Stephen Sutton's friends have seen him
fight his illness with courage and humor
the money raised in his name is they say
a fitting tribute to the man they know
it's just testament to Stephens strength
really in the determination that he's
had over the last 15 months to make sure
that that basically that his life's not
being for nothing that whatever he's
done is to support people that are going
through the same kind of journey that
Stephens been on over the last four
years on the face of it he's playing it
quite cool and he hasn't done a lot but
I think inside it'll be really really
proud considering that only it was only
a year and a half ago that he was
considering raising ten thousand pounds
phenomenal is how Stephen is said to
have described it even more remarkable
because on Tuesday he said goodbye to
his supporters he thought he was in his
words a goner but he was back online
yesterday saying he was now in high
spirits diagnosed with terminal cancer
Stephen wrote a wish list of 46 things
he wanted to do he crowd surfed in a
dinghy went skydiving played the drums
in front of 90,000 people at Wembley
hugged an elephant and even got a tattoo
and he decided to raise money for the
Teenage Cancer Trust his million pound
target was reached on Wednesday now it
stands at more than double that Stephens
story has had an incredible impact on
Teenage Cancer Trust we are a relatively
small charity raising about twelve
million pounds a year so what he has
done is changing the face of the
organization in many ways and going to
be supporting the seven young people
every day who are diagnosed with cancer
now and in the future the charity runs
more than 20 specialist units across the
UK a vital service for young people with
cancer through what he's doing right now
so many people are going to benefit from
it so but I save always got to look for
light in the darkness
so yeah I think he's great and I don't
really say often because I'm one of
those people
that gets quite cringed out about
certain things but now he's definitely
an inspiration definitely the extra
money will mean more units more nurses
more expert care for young people that
will be Steven Sutton's legacy
Angus Crawford BBC news
